00033 #ifdef __MINGW32__

00035 #       define wcout cout
00036 #       define wostringstream ostringstream
00037 #       define wstringstream stringstream
00038 #       define wcerr cerr
00039 #       define wofstream ofstream
00040 #       define wifstream ifstream

00051 #if defined _MSC_VER || defined __CYGWIN__ || defined __MINGW32__
00052 #       ifdef BUILDING_LIBRARY
00053 #               ifdef __GNUC__
00054 #                       define DLL_PUBLIC __attribute__((dllexport))
00055 #               else
00056 #                       define DLL_PUBLIC __declspec(dllexport) // Note: actually gcc seems to also supports this syntax.
00057 #               endif
00058 #       else
00059 #               ifdef __GNUC__
00060 #                       define DLL_PUBLIC __attribute__((dllimport))
00061 #               else
00062 #                       define DLL_PUBLIC __declspec(dllimport) // Note: actually gcc seems to also supports this syntax.
00063 #               endif
00064 #       endif
00065 #       define DLL_LOCAL
00066 #else
00067 #       if __GNUC__ >= 4
00068                 //use g++ -fvisibility=hidden to make all hidden except those marked DLL_PUBLIC ie "default"
00069 #               define DLL_PUBLIC __attribute__ ((visibility("default")))
00070 #               define DLL_LOCAL  __attribute__ ((visibility("hidden")))
00071 #       else
00072 #               define DLL_PUBLIC
00073 #               define DLL_LOCAL
00074 #       endif
00075 #endif

00111 
00112 /* this has been resolved somehow without removing the automatic conversion to int:
00113 Remove automatic conversion to int which takes precedence over the automatic conversion to bool
00114 and therefore causes a non-numeric error if you include a non-numeric value in an if statement like
00115 
00116  aa="xx"
00117  if (aa) {}
00118 
00119 */

00127 //stupid MS language "extensions" disable some standard C++ keywords ... restore them
00128 //http://members.ozemail.com.au/~geoffch/samples/programming/msvc/cl/options/z$e.htm
00129 //complete list of c/c++ keywords is
00130 //and, and_eq, bitand, bitor, compl, not, not_eq, or, or_eq, xor and xor_eq
00131 #ifdef _MSC_VER
00132 #define and &&
00133 #define not_eq !=
00134 #define not !
00135 #define or ||
00136 #endif

00140 //annoyingly FM as L'\xFE' doesnt work because prevents "AAA" FM "BBB"
00141 //const wchar_t FM=L'\xFE';
00142 
00143 //the var versions of the above (without leading or trailing _)
00144 //are defined AFTER the class declaration of "var"
00145 
00146 //these macros (with leading and trailing _) are wstring versions of the pick delimiters
00147 #define _IM_ L"\xFF"
00148 #define _RM_ L"\xFF"
00149 //#define _FM_ L"\376"
00150 #define _FM_ L"\xFE"
00151 #define _AM_ L"\xFE"
00152 #define _VM_ L"\xFD"
00153 #define _SM_ L"\xFC"
00154 #define _SVM_ L"\xFC"
00155 #define _TM_ L"\xFB"
00156 #define _STM_ L"\xFA"
00157 #define _SSTM_ L"\xF9"
00158 #define _DQ_ L"\""
00159 #define _SQ_ L"\'"
00160 
00161 //these macros (with trailing _) are wchar versions of the pick delimiters
00162 #define IM_ L'\xFF'
00163 #define RM_ L'\xFF'
00164 #define FM_ L'\xFE'
00165 #define AM_ L'\xFE'
00166 #define VM_ L'\xFD'
00167 #define SVM_ L'\xFC'
00168 #define SM_ L'\xFC'
00169 #define TM_ L'\xFB'
00170 #define STM_ L'\xFA'
00171 #define SSTM_ L'\xF9'
00172 #define DQ_ L'\"'
00173 #define SQ_ L'\''

00175 //the argument for utf16 http://www.unicode.org/notes/tn12/ (utf8/32 cannot handle binary because of illegal byte sequences)
00176 //win32/java/icu/python is utf16 but situation is not so clear on unix (where wchar_t is 32bit)
00177 //but see http://std.dkuug.dk/JTC1/SC22/WG14/www/docs/n1040.pdf for <uchar.h>

00179 //default to allow conversion from char to allow writing xx="abc" instead of xx=L"abc" because ease of use comes first for the application programmer
00180 //but dont allow it in the library itself because performance comes first
00181 #ifdef MV_NO_NARROW
00182         #define MV_CONSTRUCTION_FROM_CHAR_EXPLICIT explicit
00183 #else
00184         #define MV_CONSTRUCTION_FROM_CHAR_EXPLICIT
00185 #endif

00193 //#define arg const var& - too likely to conflict with things eg in postgres library
00194 //#define call - conflicts with dynamic so/dll load/call
00195 
00196 //most help from Thinking in C++ Volume 1 Chapter 12
00197 //http://www.camtp.uni-mb.si/books/Thinking-in-C++/TIC2Vone-distribution/html/Chapter12.html
00198 
00199 //could also use http://www.informit.com/articles/article.asp?p=25264&seqNum=1
00200 //which is effectively about makeing objects behave like ordinary variable syntactically
00201 //implementing smartpointers
00202 
00203 //explanation 1.
00204 //we need a thread specific environment number so that functions written in C++
00205 //and used in database calculations (via a callback to a different thread).
00206 //Database calculation functions written in c++ should use this environment number
00207 //as an index into arrays or vectors of global data and not use simple thread specific storage
00208 //explanation 2.
00209 //the SELECT statement often needs to sort/select on calculated fields and we provide a way for the database to
00210 //call procedures in the main program using pipes and a separate thread to serve the pipe.
00211 //to enhance programmability the procedures can have the environment of the thread that issued the SELECT statement
00212 //so we have two threads essentially using the same environment but because one is waiting for the
00213 //database to complete the select statement, the other thread can have free access to the same environment
00214 //each main thread gets a supporting thread the first time it does a SELECT
00215 //explanation 3.
00216 
00217 //the destructor is public non-virtual (supposedly to save space)
00218 //since this class has no virtual functions it should still be save to derive from it and do delete()
00219 //http://www.parashift.com/c++-faq-lite/virtual-functions.html#faq-20.7
00220 class DLL_PUBLIC var
00221 {
00222 
00223 protected:
00224 
00225 public:
00226         //destructor to (NOT VIRTUAL to save space since not expected to be a base class)
00227         //protected to prevent deriving from var since wish to save space and not provide virtual destructor
00228         //http://www.gotw.ca/publications/mill18.htm
00229         ~var();
00230 
00231         bool assigned() const;
00232 
00233         bool unassigned() const;
00234 
00235         //CONVERSIONS
00237 
00238         bool toBool() const;
00239 
00240         //standard c/c++ int() in other words simply take the number to the left of the point. -1.5 becomes -1 and 1.5 becomes 1
00241         int toInt() const;
00242 
00243         double toDouble() const;
00244 
00245         std::wstring towstring() const;
00246 
00247         std::string tostring() const;
00248 
00249         //CONSTRUCTORS
00251 
00252         //default ctor to allow plain unassigned "var mv;" syntax
00253         var();
00254 
00255         //copy ctor
00256         var(const var& mv1);
00257 
00258         //ctor for wchar_t
00259         var(const wchar_t char1);
00260 
00261         //ctor for wchar_t*
00262         var(const wchar_t* cstr1);
00263 
00264         //ctor for memory block
00265         var(const wchar_t* cstr1, const size_t int1);
00266 
00267         //ctor for char to create
00268         MV_CONSTRUCTION_FROM_CHAR_EXPLICIT
00269         var(const char char1);
00270 
00271         //ctor for char*
00272         MV_CONSTRUCTION_FROM_CHAR_EXPLICIT
00273         var(const char* cstr1);
00274 
00275         //ctor for char memory block
00276         MV_CONSTRUCTION_FROM_CHAR_EXPLICIT
00277         var(const char* cstr1, const size_t int1);
00278 
00279         //ctor for std::wstring
00280         var(const std::wstring& str1);
00281 
00282         //ctor for std::string
00283         var(const std::string& str1);
00284 
00285         //ctor for bool (dont allow this if no constructor for char* otherwise " " is converted to 1 in widechar only compilations
00286         MV_CONSTRUCTION_FROM_CHAR_EXPLICIT
00287         var(const bool bool1);
00288 
00289         //ctor for int
00290         var(const int int1);
00291 
00292         //ctor for double
00293         var(const double double1);
00294 
00295         //AUTOMATIC CONVERSIONS TO bool, void* and int
00297 
00298         //someone recommends not to create more than one automatic converter
00299         //to avoid the compiler error "ambiguous conversion"
00300         //explicit keyword only works on conversion TO var not conversion FROM var
00301 
00302         //commented to allow conversion to int
00303         //if you uncomment this then also uncomment the definition in var.cpp
00304         //unfortunately int takes precedence over bool somehow (unless both const/not const?)
00305         //so if x is not numeric "if (x)" gives a non-numeric error.
00306         //automatic conversion to int would be nice to avoid large numbers of specialised function calls
00307         //I think like var::extract(int, int, int);
00308 
00309         //if you uncomment this then also uncomment the definition in var.cpp
00310         //uncommented to allow simpler functions
00311         //NB const probably determines priority of choice between automatic conversion
00312         //and C++ uses bool and int conversion in certain cases to convert to int and bool
00313         //therefore have chosen to make both bool and int "const" since they dont make
00314         //and changes to the base object.
00315         operator int() const;
00316         
00317         //remove because causes "ambiguous" with -short_wchar on linux
00318         //operator unsigned int() const;
00319 
00320         //recommended to provide automatic conversion to VOID POINTER instead of direct to bool
00321         //since void* is auto converted to bool nicely for natural "if (xyz)" syntax
00322         //and doesnt suffer the "ambiguous bool promotion to int" issue that automatic conversion to bool has
00323         //why this is working here now is probably because of non-portable compiler characteristics or lack of source examples
00324         //Note: The boost::shared_ptr class support an implicit conversion to bool which is free from unintended conversion to arithmetic types. 
00325         // http://www.informit.com/guides/content.aspx?g=cplusplus&seqNum=297
00326         operator void*() const;
00327 
00328 //this stops using var as indexes of arrays on msvc since msvc converts bool and int ambiguous to index number
00329 //g++ seems happy to make int higher and unambigous with bool but probably non-standard c++
00330 //msvc (at least) cant do without this since it seems unwilling to convert void* as a bool
00331 //therefore we include it and restrict indexing on ints and not var eg for (int ii=0 .... instead of for (var ii=0 ...
00332 //#ifndef _MSVC
00333         operator bool() const;
00334 //#endif
00335 
00336         //NB && and || operators are NOT overloaded because var is set to convert to boolean automatically
00337         //this is fortunate because "shortcircuiting" of && and || doesnt happen when overloaded
00338 
00339         //operator size_t() const;
00340 
00341         //EXPLICIT CONVERSIONS TO
00343 
00344         //wstring - replicates towstring()
00345         //would allow the usage of any std::wstring function but may result
00346         //in a lot of compilation failures due to "ambiguous overload"
00347         //unfortunately there is no "explicit" keyword as for constructors - coming in C++0X
00348         //for now prevent this to ensure efficient programming
00349         //maybe optionally allow them using a compiler macro?
00350         #ifndef MV_NO_NARROW
00351                 operator std::wstring() const;
00352         #endif
00353 
00354         //string - replicates tostring()
00355         //would allow the usage of any std::string function but may result
00356         //in a lot of compilation failures due to "ambiguous overload"
00357         //unfortunately there is no "explicit" keyword as for constructors - coming in C++0X
00358         //for now prevent this to ensure efficient programming
00359         #ifndef MV_NO_NARROW
00360                 operator std::string() const;
00361         #endif
00362 
00363         //allow conversion to wchar_t (takes first wchar_t or wchar_t 0 if zero length string)
00364         //would allow the usage of any wchar_t function but may result
00365         //in a lot of compilation failures due to "ambiguous overload"
00366         //unfortunately there is no "explicit" keyword as for constructors - coming in C++0X
00367         //operator wchar_t() const;
00368 
00369         //UNARY OPERATORS
00371 
00372         //=var
00373         //The assignment operator should always return a reference to *this.
00374         //cant be (const var& mv1) because seems to cause a problem with var1=var2 in function parameters
00375         //unfortunately causes problem of passing var by value and thereby unnecessary contruction
00376         //see also ^= etc
00377         var& operator =(const var& mv1);
00378 
00379         //=int
00380         var& operator = (const int int1);
00381 
00382         //=double
00383         var& operator = (const double double1);
00384 
00385         //=wchar_t

00387

00389         var& operator = (const wchar_t* char2);
00390 
00391         //=string
00392         var& operator = (const std::wstring string2);
00393 
00394         //=var
00395         var& operator ^=(const var& mv1);
00396 
00397         //=int
00398         var& operator ^= (const int int1);
00399 
00400         //=double
00401         var& operator ^= (const double double1);
00402

00404         var& operator ^= (const wchar_t char2);
00405 
00406         //=wchar_t*
00407         var& operator ^= (const wchar_t* char2);
00408

00410         var& operator ^= (const std::wstring string2);

00413     //postfix returning void so cannot be used in expressions (avoid unreadable programs)

00418

00696         //integer() represents pick int() because int() is reserved word in c/c++
00697         //Note that integer like pick int() is the same as floor()
00698         //whereas the usual c/c++ int() simply take the next integer nearest 0 (ie cuts of any fractional decimal places)
00699         //to get the usual c/c++ effect use toInt() (although toInt() returns an int instead of a var like normal exodus functions)

01051 class DLL_PUBLIC varray
01052 {
01053 
01054 public:
01055 
01056         varray(int rows, int cols=1);
01057 
01058         bool resize(int rows, int cols=1);
01059 
01060         // subscript operators often come in pairs
01061         var& operator() (int row, int col=1);
01062         var operator() (int row, int col=1) const;
01063 
01064         varray& init(const var& mv1);
01065 
01066         //destructor to (NOT VIRTUAL to save space since not expected to be a base class)
01067         //protected to prevent deriving from var since wish to save space and not provide virtual destructor
01068         //http://www.gotw.ca/publications/mill18.htm
01069         ~varray();
01070 
01071         varray& operator = (const varray& mva1);
01072 
01073         //allow default contruction for class variables later resized in class methods
01074         varray();
01075 
01076 private:
01077 
01078         // Disable copy constructor (why?)
01079         // Copy constructor
01080         varray(const varray& m);
01081 
01082         int rows_, cols_;
01083         var* data_;
01084 
01085 }; //of class "varray"
